questions.text: After the chemotherapy session for breast carcinoma, your senior asks you to discard empty vials of paclitaxel. Which of the following bins will you discard them in?
questions.solution:
Used, discarded, and expired cytotoxic drugs, whether in plastic vacutainers, syringes, glass vials, ampoules, or glass bottles, along with the items used during the administration of cytotoxic drugs, like IV sets, gloves, dressing, and cotton swabs, are discarded into the yellow bin with cytotoxic label.

Paclitaxel is a cytotoxic drug used as a part of a regimen in breast cancer chemotherapy.

Broken or discarded and contaminated glass, including medicine vials and ampoules, except those contaminated with cytotoxic wastes are discarded in blue bins.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

 

  Yellow bag (non-chlorinated)  

Type of Waste

  Treatment and Disposal Options

Human anatomical waste

Animal anatomical waste

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial
Soiled Waste: Items like dressings, cotton swabs, and plaster casts contaminated with blood and body fluids and bags containing residual discarded blood.

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial

or

Autoclaving/Microwaving/ Hydroclaving

Later - Shredding/mutilation
Discarded linen, mattresses, beddings contaminated with blood or body fluid, routine masks, and gowns

Non- chlorinated chemical disinfection
followed by incineration or Plazma
Pyrolysis or for energy recovery.
In absence of the above facilities, shredding, mutilation, or a combination of sterilization and shredding is used.

Microbiology, biotechnology, clinical laboratory waste

(Autoclave safe plastic bags used)

Blood bags, laboratory
cultures, stocks or specimens of microorganisms,
live or attenuated vaccines, human and animal cell cultures used in research, industrial laboratories, production of biological, residual toxins, dishes, and devices used for cultures.

Pre-treatment with nonchlorinated chemicals

Later - Incineration

Expired/discarded medicine, cytotoxic drugs

 Incineration/plasma pyrolysis/ disposal in a secured landfill
 

Chemical waste

Chemicals used in biological production and used or discarded
disinfectants.

Disposal- incineration/plasma
pyrolysis

Encapsulation- hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facility.

Chemical liquid waste :
Liquid waste generated due to the use of chemicals in the production of
biological and used or discarded disinfectants, silver X-ray film
developing liquid,
discarded formalin,
infected secretions,
aspirated body fluids, liquid from laboratories and floor washings, cleaning, house-keeping and
disinfecting activities etc.

 

 After resource recovery, the chemical
liquid waste shall be pre-treated before mixing with other wastewater. 

 

  Red bag (non-chlorinated)  
 Type of Waste

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Recyclable contaminated waste

Contaminated waste tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes with their needles cut), vacutainers with needles cut, and gloves.

Autoclaving/Microwaving/
Hydroclaving

Followed by Shredding/mutilation

And later, Energy recovery/Plastics to diesel or fuel oil/road-making

Not to be sent to landfill

 

  White (translucent)  
(puncture-proof, leak-proof containers)
Type of Waste

Treatment and Disposal Options

Waste Sharps including metals.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutter or burner, scalpels, blades, or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. This includes both used, discarded, and contaminated metal sharps

Autoclaving/ Dry heat sterilization

Followed by - Shredding/mutilation/
encapsulation

Later by - Iron foundries/sanitary landfill/waste sharps

 

   Blue  
(Puncture proof and leak proof containers with blue colored marking)

Type of Waste 

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Glassware

Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampules except those containing cytotoxic waste.

Metallic body implants

Sodium hypochlorite/Autoclaving/
Microwaving/Hydroclaving

Later - Recycling

 

 Note: Ash from the incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at a common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may also be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: A new nurse asks your advice regarding the disposal of an unsterile vacutainer. In response, you would answer her to dispose of it in ____.
questions.solution:
The contaminated vacutainer to be discarded in the red bag or container. As the vacutainer comes under recyclable contaminated waste.

questions.text: According to biomedical waste management protocols, which of the following colored bins should the instrument shown below be discarded in?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a dynamic hip screw and it should be discarded in the blue colored bin.

All metallic body implants except metallic sharps are discarded in the blue bin. Metallic sharps (scalpels, blades, needles, etc) are discarded in white or translucent bins.

Other options:

Option A: White (translucent) containers are puncture-proof and leakproof. It is used for the disposal of waste sharps including metals.

Option C: Yellow containers are lined with yellow non-chlorinated plastic bags. It is used for the disposal of anatomical wastes, discarded medicines, and clinical laboratory waste.

Option D: Red containers are lined with red non-chlorinated bags. Recyclable contaminated waste such as intravenous tubes, catheters, and urine bags are discarded in these containers. 

The following image shows the various logos signifying specific types of wastes.

Related Pearl: Biomedical Waste (BMW) Management -COVID 19

In addition to the current BMW Management rules, the following measures are proposed

  • To report opening/operation of COVID 19 Ward/ICU/Lab/Collection Centre to SPCB (State Pollution Control Board) and CBWTF (Common Biomedical Waste Treatment Facility) in that area
  • Dedicated sanitation workers deputed only to collect COVID 19 BMW
  • It is mandatory for all BMW bags and containers from COVID 19 areas to carry "COVID 19 WASTE" label
  • Keep separate colour coded bins with foot operated lids
  • The inner and outer surfaces of these containers must be disinfected daily with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution
  • To ensure no leaks, double layers (2 bags) are used
COLOUR OF THE BIN PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT(PPE) OTHER WASTE
Red Bin
  • Goggles
  • Face shield 
  • Splash-proof apron
  • Plastic coverall
  • Hazmat suit
  • Nitrile gloves
  • Used gloves

Laboratory waste

  • Pre-treated viral transport media
  • Plastic vials and cryovials
  • Vacutainers
  • Eppendorf tubes
  • Pipette tips
Yellow Bin
  • Used mask(triple layer mask, N95 mask)
  • Head cover/Cap, Shoe cover
  • Disposable linen gown 
  • Non-plastic/Semi-plastic coverall

 

  • Diapers with feces of immobile COVID 19 patients

questions.text: A nurse comes to you for advice regarding the disposal of a used insulin syringe. Which of the following containers would you advise her to use?
questions.solution:
Insulin syringes are syringes with fixed needles, which are to be disposed in White (puncture, leak and tamper proof) containers.

Other options are explained in the pearl given below.

questions.text: An intern asks for your advice regarding the disposal of needles from the needle tip cutter after a vaccine drive. Which of the following bins will you advise her to discard them in?
questions.solution:
Waste sharps including metals (both used, discarded, and contaminated metal sharps) are to be discarded in the white bin.

questions.text: The following equipment with a sample was sent from the COVID-19 positive ward for testing. Where should the empty container be disposed of?
questions.solution:
The image shows an Eppendorf micro-centrifugation tube. It should be discarded in red bin.

These are single-use disposable tubes used for storing human test samples (except blood) for in-vitro testing. The tube is sensitive to temperature and seals may breach in higher temperatures.

Related Pearl: Biomedical Waste (BMW) Management -COVID 19

  • To report opening/operation of COVID 19 Ward/ICU/Lab/Collection Centre to SPCB (State Pollution Control Board) and CBWTF (Common Biomedical Waste Treatment Facility) in that area

  • It is mandatory for all BMW bags and containers from COVID 19 areas to carry "COVID 19 WASTE" label
  • Keep separate colour coded bins with foot operated lids
  • The inner and outer surfaces of these containers must be disinfected daily with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution

questions.text: In which of the following bags are latex gloves disposed of after use?
questions.solution:
Latex gloves are disposed of in red-colored bag after use.

biological and used or discarded disinfectants, silver X-ray film
developing liquid,
discarded formalin,
infected secretions,
aspirated body fluids, liquid from laboratories and floor washings, cleaning, house-keeping and
disinfecting activities etc.

 

 After resource recovery, the chemical
liquid waste shall be pre-treated before mixing with other wastewater. 

 

  Red bag (non-chlorinated)  
 Type of Waste

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Recyclable contaminated waste

Contaminated waste tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes with their needles cut), vacutainers with needles cut, and gloves.

Autoclaving/Microwaving/
Hydroclaving

Followed by Shredding/mutilation

And later, Energy recovery/Plastics to diesel or fuel oil/road-making

Not to be sent to landfill

 

  White (translucent)  
(puncture-proof, leak-proof containers)
Type of Waste

Treatment and Disposal Options

Waste Sharps including metals.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutter or burner, scalpels, blades, or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. This includes both used, discarded, and contaminated metal sharps

Autoclaving/ Dry heat sterilization

Followed by - Shredding/mutilation/
encapsulation

Later by - Iron foundries/sanitary landfill/waste sharps

 

   Blue  
(Puncture proof and leak proof containers with blue colored marking)

Type of Waste 

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Glassware

Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampules except those containing cytotoxic waste.

Metallic body implants

Sodium hypochlorite/Autoclaving/
Microwaving/Hydroclaving

Later - Recycling

 

 Note: Ash from the incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at a common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may also be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: According to biomedical waste management, used pacemakers should be disposed of in which of the following colored bag?
questions.solution:
According to biomedical waste management, used pacemakers should be disposed of in a blue colored bag. All the metallic body implants and glasswares are discarded in a blue colored bag.

questions.text: A young male was managed with the following cast for a closed fracture of the leg, which was associated with few abrasions over the ankle. According to biomedical waste management, this cast should be disposed of in which of the following bins?
questions.solution:
According to biomedical waste management, used plaster casts, contaminated with body fluids, should be disposed of in a yellow colored bag. All the soiled waste items like dressings, cotton swabs and plaster casts are discarded in the yellow bin.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases should healthcare workers involved in handling biomedical waste be vaccinated against?
questions.solution:
Healthcare workers involved in handling biomedical waste should be vaccinated against hepatitis B and tetanus.

These are most likely to be transmitted by the handling of biomedical waste. Yearly health check-ups should be done, and a booster dose should be given if needed.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a high-heat system for the treatment of biomedical waste?
questions.solution:
Microwaving is a low-heat system for the treatment of biomedical waste.

The heating systems used for the treatment and disposal of biomedical waste are:

Low-heat system High-heat system

Autoclaving: Uses steam. It is of two types-

  1. Gravity flow autoclave 
  2. Vacuum autoclave

Microwaving: Uses moist heat and steam generated by microwave energy

Incineration: Waste is destroyed/denatured under high temperatures 

Plasma pyrolysis: Waste is treated at high temperatures under controlled conditions to form gases that are subjected to combustion in the secondary chamber

Hydroclaving: The waste is subjected to indirect heating by applying steam to the outer jacket

Dry heat sterilization: Waste sharps are treated using dry heat at a temperature >185 C for 150 minutes

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 18 weeks of gestation with bleeding per vagina had a miscarriage. The products of conception are sent for appropriate tests. Which of the following is not a disposal option for the same?
questions.solution:
Encapsulation is not a disposal option for human anatomical waste. It is a disposal technique used for expired and discarded medicines along with chemical wastes. 

Human anatomical waste such as an aborted fetus is put in a yellow bag and is disposed of by either incineration, plasma pyrolysis, or deep burial. 

The biomedical waste management rule is applicable to all those who collect, receive, store, dispose and treat biomedical waste. The wastes are categorised and segregated at the point of generation of waste. A color coding system with 4 colors namely yellow, red, white, and blue is used for waste segregation. 

The segregated waste is then disposed of by various methods. They are:

  • Incineration - this is a dry oxidation process done using high temperatures. The types are rotary kiln, pyrolytic incinerator, and single chamber incinerator.  
  • Chemical disinfection - chemicals are added to waste to kill or inactivate the microorganisms. Mostly used for treating liquid wastes. 
  • Wet and dry thermal treatment - shredded infectious waste is exposed to high temperature, high-pressure steam and it resembles an autoclave sterilization process. 
  • Microwave irradiation - microorganisms are killed using high-frequency microwaves. Its efficiency should be checked routinely. 
  • Land disposal - either municipal disposal sites or sanitary landfills are used. 
  • Inertization - waste is mixed with cement and other substances before disposal to reduce toxicity. 

Disposal by deep burial is permitted only in rural areas which lack common bio-medical treatment facilities. Permission from the concerned authority is needed and guidelines issued by the central pollution control board should be followed. 

Cytotoxic and biohazard materials will have separate non-washable and visible symbols as shown below:

questions.text: You would advise on-site chemical pre-treatment before incineration for all of the following biomedical waste except ____
questions.solution:
Urine bags do not have to undergo on-site chemical pre-treatment to sterilize before handing them over for incineration.

As per NACO or WHO guidelines, laboratory waste, microbiological waste, blood samples, blood bags should be sterilized with non-chlorinated chemicals on-site. After this, it should be handed over to the common bio-medical waste treatment and disposal facility for incineration.

questions.text: The type of waste related to the image depicted is disposed by:
questions.solution:
The image depicts radiation. Radioactive wastes do not come under the purview of biomedical waste management. It can be reprocessed to extract nuclear fuel or encased in glass and left deep underground.

The rules of Biomedical waste management do not apply to:

  • Radioactive wastes
  • Municipal solid waste
  • Lead acid batteries
  • E-waste

questions.text: All the treated waste from these bins can be sent to undergo any of the following disposal options except____
questions.solution:
The given red bins collect recyclable contaminated waste. It should not be sent to landfill sites as they contain plastics.

Treatment and disposal of recyclable contaminated waste are by autoclaving/ microwaving/ hydroclaving. It is followed by shredding/ mutilation. Then it is sent to registered or authorized recyclers. It can also be sent for energy recovery/ plastics to diesel or fuel oil/ for road making.

questions.text:
Identify the correct sequence of doffing the PPE kit.
  1. Remove outer gloves and perform hand hygiene.
  2. Remove shoe covers only by touching the other surface and perform hand hygiene.
  3. Remove eyepiece by holding the straps and perform hand hygiene.
  4. Remove gown slowly by holding the gown at the waist and pulling, without touching the outer surface.
  5. Remove inner gloves and perform hand hygiene.
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of doffing (removing) the PPE kit is 2, 1, 3, 4, 5.

Preparation for doffing the PPE:

  • To be performed only in the designated area
  • Check for any leak or soiling
  • The doffing room should have two chairs, dirty and clean
  • All the PPE must be discarded in the red bin
  • Hand hygiene must be performed after every step

Steps of doffing the PPE:

  • Engage the observer and ask him to check the PPE - observer should check for any leak, tear, or contamination of PPE. If contaminated, then it should be disinfected with alcohol-based wipes.
  • Disinfect the gloves
  • Remove and discard shoe covers
  • Disinfect and remove the outer pair of gloves
  • Disinfect inner gloves
  • Remove face shield/eye goggle - loosen the screw and remove the face shield by holding it from the back handle. Discard it.
  • Remove hood and cover all (gown)
    • Holding the suit at the arms, slide it off the shoulder slightly, then pull the suit from the side of the waist
    • Roll the arms out one by one
  • Disinfect and remove inner gloves
  • Perform hand hygiene and wear a new pair of gloves
  • Remove and discard N-95 mask
  • Disinfect gloves
  • Sit on the clean chair and disinfect shoes using alcohol wipes
  • Disinfect and remove gloves
  • Perform hand hygiene
  • Wipe the shoes on the sodium hypochlorite soaked doormat at the exit
  • Exit the doffing area and take a shower

questions.text: Which of the following items is least suited for disposal in a landfill?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the urinary bag, which is a plastic waste is the least suitable for disposal in a landfill. 

Plastic wastes such as urinary bags are disposed of in the red bin and should not be sent to landfill. Plastic waste can be sent for diesel, fuel oil and road making.

Waste sharps including metals can be disposed of by autoclaving or dry heat sterilisation ---> shredding/ mutilation/ encapsulation in metal containers or cement concrete ---> final disposal in a sanitary landfill or designated concrete waste sharp pit or be sent to approved iron foundries.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

 

  Yellow bag (non-chlorinated)  

Type of Waste

  Treatment and Disposal Options

Human anatomical waste

Animal anatomical waste

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial
Soiled Waste: Items like dressings, cotton swabs, and plaster casts contaminated with blood and body fluids and bags containing residual discarded blood.

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial

or

Autoclaving/Microwaving/ Hydroclaving

Later - Shredding/mutilation
Discarded linen, mattresses, beddings contaminated with blood or body fluid, routine masks, and gowns

Non- chlorinated chemical disinfection
followed by incineration or Plazma
Pyrolysis or for energy recovery.
In absence of the above facilities, shredding, mutilation, or a combination of sterilization and shredding is used.

Microbiology, biotechnology, clinical laboratory waste

(Autoclave safe plastic bags used)

Blood bags, laboratory
cultures, stocks or specimens of microorganisms,
live or attenuated vaccines, human and animal cell cultures used in research, industrial laboratories, production of biological, residual toxins, dishes, and devices used for cultures.

Pre-treatment with nonchlorinated chemicals

Later - Incineration

Expired/discarded medicine, cytotoxic drugs

 Incineration/plasma pyrolysis/ disposal in a secured landfill
 

Chemical waste

Chemicals used in biological production and used or discarded
disinfectants.

Disposal- incineration/plasma
pyrolysis

Encapsulation- hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facility.

Chemical liquid waste :
Liquid waste generated due to the use of chemicals in the production of
biological and used or discarded disinfectants, silver X-ray film
developing liquid,
discarded formalin,
infected secretions,
aspirated body fluids, liquid from laboratories and floor washings, cleaning, house-keeping and
disinfecting activities etc.

 

 After resource recovery, the chemical
liquid waste shall be pre-treated before mixing with other wastewater. 

 

  Red bag (non-chlorinated)  
 Type of Waste

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Recyclable contaminated waste

Contaminated waste tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes with their needles cut), vacutainers with needles cut, and gloves.

Autoclaving/Microwaving/
Hydroclaving

Followed by Shredding/mutilation

And later, Energy recovery/Plastics to diesel or fuel oil/road-making

Not to be sent to landfill

 

  White (translucent)  
(puncture-proof, leak-proof containers)
Type of Waste

Treatment and Disposal Options

Waste Sharps including metals.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutter or burner, scalpels, blades, or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. This includes both used, discarded, and contaminated metal sharps

Autoclaving/ Dry heat sterilization

Followed by - Shredding/mutilation/
encapsulation

Later by - Iron foundries/sanitary landfill/waste sharps

 

   Blue  
(Puncture proof and leak proof containers with blue colored marking)

Type of Waste 

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Glassware

Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampules except those containing cytotoxic waste.

Metallic body implants

Sodium hypochlorite/Autoclaving/
Microwaving/Hydroclaving

Later - Recycling

 

 Note: Ash from the incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at a common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may also be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: According to biomedical waste management, what is the appropriate method of treatment for the instrument shown below?
questions.solution:
The appropriate method of treatment of the intraosseous needle, shown in the image, is autoclaving.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutters or burners, scalpels, blades, or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause punctures and cuts are disposed of in white, translucent, puncture-proof, and leak-proof containers. They are treated by autoclaving/ dry heat sterilization followed by - shredding/mutilation/encapsulation and later sent to iron foundries/sanitary landfills.

Autoclaving is a method of heat sterilization. The autoclave is a device that uses steam under pressure to sterilize linen, instruments, laboratory ware, media, pharmaceutical products, aqueous solutions, surgical instruments, cardiac catheters, and implants.

The image given below shows an autoclave.

The biomedical waste management rule applies to all those who collect, receive, store, dispose, and treat biomedical waste. The wastes are categorized and segregated at the point of generation of waste. A color coding system with 4 colors namely yellow, red, white, and blue is used for waste segregation. 

The segregated waste is then treated by various methods. They are:

  • Incineration (Option B)- this is a dry oxidation process done using high temperatures. The types are rotary kiln, pyrolytic incinerator, and single chamber incinerator.  
  • Chemical disinfection (Option D)- chemicals are added to waste to kill or inactivate the microorganisms. Mostly used for treating liquid wastes. 
  • Wet and dry thermal treatment - shredded infectious waste is exposed to high temperature, high-pressure steam and it resembles an autoclave sterilization process. 
  • Microwave irradiation (Option A) - microorganisms are killed using high-frequency microwaves. Its efficiency should be checked routinely.

Later disposed of by -

  • Iron foundries/sanitary landfill
  • Inertization: Waste is mixed with cement to reduce toxicity. 

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

 

  Yellow bag (non-chlorinated)
